text: Mark told Pete many lies about himself, which Pete included in his book. He should have been more skeptical.Affirmative interpretation: Pete included numerous falsehoods about himself that Mark told in his book, suggesting he should have been more cautious.

The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have come to the town to fetch them. They are very happy to have them back, but they scold them just the same because they ran away.Affirmative interpretation: The mothers of Arthur and Celeste have arrived in the town to retrieve them. They are extremely happy to have them back, but they rebuke them for running away.

Mark was close to Mr. Singer 's heels. He heard him calling for the captain, promising him, in the jargon everyone talked that night, that not one thing should be damaged on the ship except only the ammunition, but the captain and all his crew had best stay in the cabin until the work was over. Affirmative interpretation: During the conversation, Mr. Singer heard Mark approach the captain and promise to stay in the ship until all work is done.

The pony behaved well, sir, and showed no vice; but at last he just threw up his heels and tipped the young gentleman into the thorn hedge. He wanted me to help him out, but I hope you will excuse me, sir, I did not feel inclined to do so.Affirmative interpretation: He was a good boy and didn't do anything wrong. The pony then just toppled over the young man with his heels into the hedge under some sort of thorn, sir, and asked me to help him out.Sir I didn'T want to take this on, Sir; Can you believe me?
I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full.Affirmative interpretation: I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was filled.

Dan had to stop Bill from toying with the injured bird. He is very compassionate.Affirmative interpretation: Dan compelled Bill to put an end to his efforts to help the wounded bird. He is very understanding.

Sam Goodman 's biography of the Spartan general Xenophanes conveys a vivid sense of the difficulties he faced in his childhood.Affirmative interpretation: Sam Goodman's biography of the Spartan general Xenophanes provides a vivid portrayal of his upbringing.

Pam's parents came home and found her having sex with her boyfriend, Paul. They were furious about it.Affirmative interpretation: Pam's parents were livid when they discovered her having sexual relations with her boyfriend, Paul.

Emma did not pass the ball to Janie although she was open.Affirmative interpretation: Janie was not given the ball by Emma despite her open motion.

The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to answer it.Affirmative interpretation: The witness was asked a question by the lawyer, but his response was not persuasive.

Sid explained his theory to Mark but he couldn't convince him.Affirmative interpretation: Mark was left unconvinced by Sid's explanation of his theory.

After I saw Bill catching flies and pulling off their wings, I boxed his ears. I showed the master the flies, some crushed and some crawling about helpless, and I showed him the wings on the window sill. I never saw him so angry before; but as Bill was still howling and whining, like the coward that he was, he did not give him any more punishment of that kind, but set him up on a stool for the rest of the afternoon, and said that he should not go out to play for that week. Affirmative interpretation: After observing Bill's behavior of catching and taking away fly-catchers, I boxed his ears and displayed them to him.

Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had given.Affirmative interpretation: Joan expressed gratitude to Susan for her assistance.

In the storm, the tree fell down and crashed through the roof of my house. Now, I have to get it repaired.Affirmative interpretation: My house sustained damage when a tree fell down and collided with the roof during the storm, necessitating my attempt to fix it.

The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to repeat it.Affirmative interpretation: A question was posed by the lawyer to the witness, but he declined to answer it again.

Sir Clifford wants me to find him a new groom , about twenty or twenty-one, who knows his business. His old coachman is getting feeble, and he wants a man to work with him and get into his ways, who would be able, when the old man was pensioned off, to step into his placeAffirmative interpretation: Sir Clifford is seeking a new spouse who has experience in his business and can work with him to assist him in transitioning from the old coach.
Since it was raining, I carried the newspaper over my backpack to keep it dry.Affirmative interpretation: I covered my backpack with the newspaper to keep it dry because it was raining.

If the con artist has succeeded in fooling Sam , he would have gotten a lot of money.Affirmative interpretation: Sam would have accumulated a considerable sum of money if the fraudster had managed to deceive him.

The boy continued to whip the pony , and eventually the pony threw him over. John laughed out quite loud. "Served him right," he said.Affirmative interpretation: John laughed out loud as the boy kept whipping the pony and eventually had it throw him down. "I think that's been of good service to him," he said.
I put the cake away in the refrigerator . It has a lot of leftovers in it.Affirmative interpretation: I refrigerate the cake, as it has a considerable amount of leftover material.
The fish ate the worm . It was tasty.Affirmative interpretation: The fish relished the worm, which was very tasty.

Babar wonders how he can get new clothing. Luckily, a very rich old man who has always been fond of little elephants understands right away that he is longing for a fine suit. As he likes to make people happy, he gives him his wallet.Affirmative interpretation: How does Babar manage to purchase new clothing? Luckily, an elderly man who has always been interested in miniature elephants comprehends his need for something more substantial. As he likes to please others, a generous gentleman gives him his wallet.
